text: The irony is - a PhD doesn't prepare most people to actually do data engineering using industry best practices.

elements.text: The irony is - a PhD doesn't prepare most people to actually do data engineering using industry best practices.

text: I have a PhD or whatever, but I worked at a place where everyone started at the bottom. It was interesting, there's the whole "who gives a shit what you did, until you work here for 2 yrs we don't know your value". But, I also heard arguments as to why Ph.D's were "good workers". Mostly that Ph.D's tend to be able to make it work under duress no matter what the hell happens with or without help. That said - I know people who graduated who couldn't do anything independently. So, the fascination of Ph.D's is weird.

elements.text: I have a PhD or whatever, but I worked at a place where everyone started at the bottom. text: so basically people realized routine data scientists can't set up infrastructure to save their lives. Basically a DE is someone who makes all the infrastructure around DS applications.

text: its kinda like a mix of a DBA, a backend web dev, and a dev ops person or something

elements.text: its kinda like a mix of a DBA, a backend web dev, and a dev ops person or something

text:
Also note the size of the company matters too. As a DS in a startup, youre often expected to do the majority of DE work in the company. 
So many times DS is used to refer to DE as well in a rather confusing way.

elements.text:

text: small companies make DS's do literally everything. From software engineering to front end. I've lived it lol. Not fun, nor practical, but I learned a lot.
